text: Iran Air, the Iranian national airline, announced it has signed a deal to purchase 30 new aircraft from Boeing. The deal is worth $3 billion and includes the sale of 15 Boeing 737 MAXs and 15 Boeing 777s. The agreement follows a landmark nuclear deal that has eased economic sanctions against Iran. Iran Air is the second largest airline in the Middle East and its new acquisitions are a sign of its ambitious expansion plans. The deal is a huge win for Boeing, who has not sold planes to Iran for years due to US sanctions. Iran Air expects the new fleet to arrive in the next two years and will allow the airline to carry out more flights to long-haul destinations.

A Paris church has launched a contactless card donation scheme in a bid to make it easier for visitors to give. The scheme, which allows worshippers and visitors to simply tap their card on a device in the church to donate, was unveiled by the Bishop of Paris on Saturday. The move reflects a growing trend amongst European churches to take advantage of new technology to help those in need. The scheme was welcomed by the local community, with many hailing the church's effort to harness technology for a good cause. The scheme is the latest in a series of donation innovations by the church. Recently, the church has also experimented with crypto donations and cashless collection methods.

Indian Parliament was disrupted today when an unknown individual sprayed pepper spray into the chamber. It resulted in the House being forced to adjourn and many members of parliament complaining of feeling sick.The individual has been identified as a protestor, and has been arrested by security forces. It is unknown what their motivation was for disrupting the proceedings.Security forces are now working to ensure that the proceedings in Parliament can continue and that the same incident does not reoccur.The incident has been condemned by both sides of the political aisle and many other organisations. A funeral is being planned for Jakelin Caal, the 7-year-old Guatemalan migrant who died while in Border Patrol custody on December 8th. Native American women face high rates of crime despite reforms in the justice system, new data suggests. Meanwhile, Native American women are also subjected to an arrest rate that is 4.4 times higher than the arrest rate of white women, with Native American women being the most likely group to experience police brutality.The results of the study suggest that despite reforms, native women continue to face unfair treatment and criminalization. US-backed forces in Syria admitted to facing "difficulties" in the fight against Islamic State (IS) on Monday, with the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) warning that the situation could quickly deteriorate if they do not receive reinforcements. The SDF – an alliance of Kurdish and Arab forces backed by a US-led coalition - have been making steady gains since launching an offensive to liberate Raqqa, the IS stronghold in Syria, from the militants. But they warned that the battle against the IS will be "very hard and dangerous" if they are not given reinforcements. "If we don't get any more reinforcements, especially from the coalition, the progress of the fight will slow and it will be very hard and dangerous," the SDF spokesman Talal Silo said. The US has sent heavy weapons to the SDF and is providing air support in the fight for Raqqa, but it has not been able to fully take control of the city.

The United Nations World Food Programme has recently reported that nearly 12 million people are still in urgent need of emergency food assistance in Southern Africa. The food crisis in this region is primarily due to poor rainfall, drought and floods which have devastated crops and left many people without enough food to eat. The World Food Programme has been providing emergency food aid to those who are worst off, but they have warned that the funds they have available are dwindling. In order to maintain their operations they have urged donors to step in and provide funding to ensure that those who are most vulnerable do not suffer the consequences of the current crisis.

WASHINGTON/BEIJING – The US and China are closely watching the newly elected leader of the Philippines Rodrigo Duterte to determine his stance on the South China Sea dispute. Both nations want to avoid a potential military confrontation with the Philippines that would undermine their interests.Duterte has taken a hardline approach to tackling the issue since his inauguration in June, pledging to take “drastic measures” if Beijing does not agree to bilateral talks on the disputed islands in the South China Sea.China claims almost the entire South China Sea as its own, and has been ramping up its military presence there for several years. The Philippines and Vietnam, as well as a host of other nations, lay claim to parts of the sea. The US has been increasingly vocal about its interests in the region and last month conducted joint military patrols with the Philippines in the disputed waters.If Duterte is not willing to back down from his position, Beijing and Washington could find themselves in direct confrontation over the issue. The US has made it clear it will not stand for any unilateral actions by China in the South China Sea, while Beijing has made it clear that it will defend its interests in the region.While the US and China have both been pushing for dialogue with the Philippines, Duterte has so far made no promises on bilateral talks. Both countries are waiting to see if he will follow through on his tougher rhetoric and take action, or whether he will seek to reduce tensions and open the path for dialogue.

NASA astronaut Ricky Arnold recently photographed an astonishing Oklahoma-shaped corn maze from the International Space Station. The astronaut, who is from Oklahoma, was astonished by the accuracy of the maze, which he photographed using the station's 400mm lens. The maze, located near Enid, Oklahoma, was created by the Maize in the City family farm in partnership with the state's Department of Agriculture. It's become a popular attraction in the state. NASA shared Arnold's image on social media, where it's received praise for its unique design and its representation of Oklahoma's rich agricultural history.

Police arrested dozens of "Occupy Boston" protesters on Monday during a series of coordinated demonstrations against financial and political inequality in the American capital. The protesters were part of a wider movement organized by the Occupy Wall Street movement, calling for financial reforms and a more equitable distribution of wealth. The protestors gathered in the city center chanting slogans and making their demands heard. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres on Thursday called on world leaders to redouble their efforts to achieve the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals. Speaking at the General Assembly's high-level meeting in New York, Guterres said the world had made significant progress toward the 2030 targets, but still had a lot of work left to do. “Now is the moment to redouble our efforts. It is time to focus on results,” he said, citing the threat of climate change, inequality and conflict. He said the success of the goals would rely heavily on strong national leadership and effective partnerships between governments, the private sector and civil society.

US National Security Adviser John Bolton revealed Wednesday that President Trump is planning a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin next month in Paris. The White House is reportedly considering several options for a face-to-face meeting between the two leaders. Bolton also said that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and his Russian counterpart, Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, have had discussions on the matter in recent days. The exact date of the meeting has not yet been determined.Bolton’s comments come after Trump and Putin held an informal meeting in the sidelines of the Group of 20 summit in Osaka, Japan last month. The meeting was criticized by some lawmakers who argued that the talks between the two leaders should have been more closely monitored. Bolton, however, argued that any potential meeting in Paris would be “very different” from the one in Osaka. He said that a more formal meeting would include not only the two presidents but also their respective staffs and other officials.Bolton also said that the US and Russia have yet to come to an agreement on other issues such as Ukraine and the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which the US announced its intention to withdraw from in February. Recent terrorist attacks have prompted a dramatic increase in international security, with countries around the world implementing measures to protect citizens. US retail sales unexpectedly dipped in May, highlighting the challenges facing the world’s largest economy.Retail sales fell 0.5 percent last month after increasing a downwardly revised 0.3 percent in April, data from the Commerce Department showed on Wednesday. This compared with a 0.6 percent gain expected by economists.Following the weak retail sales reading, the 10-year Treasury yield slid to its lowest level since October, while the S&P 500 stock index slipped as well.Weak retail sales growth in the U.S. points to a slowdown in the economy and could suggest that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates sooner rather than later. This would be the first rate cut since 2008.The weak retail sales also echo a slowdown in the manufacturing sector, adding to a bleak economic outlook.Despite the disappointing sales report, May’s consumer sentiment reached its highest level since 2015.

A judge in California recently blocked plans to build a section of wall along the U.S.-Mexico border. While the battle continues over the wall, the judge’s decision will provide temporary relief to opponents of the wall.

The United Nations (UN) is calling for the development of an Ebola recovery strategy after the deadly virus has taken the lives of more than 2,000 people in West Africa. The new strategy, according to the UN, should focus on helping the affected regions recover economically and socially from the Ebola outbreak, in addition to providing medical assistance.In a statement, the head of the UN Mission for Ebola Emergency Response (UNMEER), Anthony Banbury, has said that the global community needs to do more than provide medical aid and resources to combat the virus. He urged the international community to work together to develop an integrated strategy to help rebuild health care systems and infrastructure in the affected regions, as well as support programs for education and jobs.The UN has said that it will provide US$128 million to finance the recovery plans. West African schools have been struggling to survive for a long time due to a lack of money, corruption, and overcrowding. The education systems are still suffering as a result, and it seems unlikely they will be able to recover from these issues any time soon.Despite being an area that is known for its wealth of natural resources, West African countries are often cash-strapped and have trouble affording school supplies, let alone paying teachers a competitive wage. The governments of the countries are often marred by corruption and political turmoil, which takes away from the amount of money that can go to schools. Many West African countries have also experienced a rapid growth in population, which has left schools dangerously overcrowded.This issue is especially pronounced in rural areas, where schools are often in disrepair and the teachers are often untrained. The students also have little access to textbooks, and often have to make do with only the most basic supplies.It is clear that West African schools are in desperate need of help if they are to overcome the issues they are currently facing. It is time for governments and non-profit organizations to come together and help make a positive difference in the lives of these children.

The Swiss Red Cross has reported that a Swiss nurse who was kidnapped in the Philippines two months ago has walked free. The nurse, who is a 47-year-old woman named Beatrice Maran, had been captured by the al-Qaeda linked Abu Sayyaf group. She was taken captive in April while she was working at a remote medical mission. According to the International Committee of the Red Cross, Ms. Maran is safe and unharmed and is currently on her way to be reunited with her family. The Swiss Red Cross was able to confirm her release on Sunday after receiving confirmation from the Philippine authorities. Ms. Maran, who has a background in public health, had been working with the International Committee of the Red Cross for several years. She was abducted during her first mission to the Philippines. Swiss Foreign Minister Didier Burkhalter expressed relief and joy at Ms. Maran's release. This story has received a lot of international attention and many are relieved to hear of her safe return.

Amnesty International is calling on the International Criminal Court to conduct a full investigation into Boko Haram for alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity. The plea comes after Amnesty has published a report documenting a wide range of human rights abuses committed in the conflict between the Islamist armed group and the Nigerian military. Amnesty has presented evidence that the military has been engaging in a campaign of violence and intimidation in the northeastern regions of Nigeria that has left thousands of people dead and traumatized. Many of the victims were innocent civilians. "It is high time the ICC opened a full investigation into these horrific crimes and took steps to ensure justice for the thousands of victims of Boko Haram's brutality", said Osai Ojigho, Amnesty's Director for Nigeria. "The ICC must send a clear message to all parties involved in the conflict that they will be held accountable for these crimes against humanity and war crimes". The Amnesty report also calls on Nigeria to properly investigate and prosecute the Boko Haram conflict abuses at the national level, while demanding that the international community supports the country's efforts to end impunity and protect its people.

Exaggerator won the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, June 11, in a close race against Stradivari. Jockey Kent Desormeaux guided the three-year-old thoroughbred down the stretch and crossed the finish line first by half a length. The win is Exaggerator's first victory in a major race this year and it gives him the chance to become the eleventh horse to win the coveted Triple Crown. The race was exciting from start to finish with multiple lead changes and jockey Desormeaux making a last minute push to get Exaggerator ahead. The victory is a sweet one for trainer Keith Desormeaux and his brother, Kent, the jockey, as Exaggerator was the first horse they ever owned together. With his win on Saturday, Exaggerator now has a legitimate shot at winning the Triple Crown. The Belmont Stakes will be held on June 11, and will mark Exaggerator's final race of the season. A win would make him the 13th horse to win the Triple Crown and only the second since Affirmed accomplished the feat in 1978.

California's Catholic Bishops are facing a sexual abuse lawsuit after victims came forward with allegations of child molestation and rape by priests. The plaintiffs are accusing the bishops of failing to protect children and cover up the crimes committed by the priests.The suit names all of the state's Roman Catholic bishops as defendants. Victims have been coming forward and seeking justice for the crimes committed against them and a way to prevent future abuse.

Pakistan has accused the US of undermining its efforts to negotiate a peace deal with the Taliban, claiming Washington scuttled the talks by changing its stance on a prisoner exchange. The governments of south and southeast Asian countries are facing an uphill battle against bird flu outbreaks as the virus continues to spread. Russia has boycotted the Eurovision 2021 song contest, hosted in Kyiv, Ukraine, amid a controversy over the selection of Ukrainian singer Anastasia Karavaeva. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson signaled a harder line stance of the Trump administration on Cuba, marking the first departure from the Obama-era policies that eased diplomatic relations with the island nation. The conflict has led to a humanitarian catastrophe that has pushed millions into extreme poverty, forcing them to flee their homes in search of safety. The upcoming elections represent an opportunity to end the crisis and bring a sense of normalcy back to the country. Peacekeeping troops have been deployed to help maintain stability and oversee the elections, which will be the first presidential ballot since 2016. CAR citizens are optimistic that a new president can help create a better future for the country.

Refugees in Belgium expressed concern Tuesday of potential retribution against them as a result of the attacks in Paris that left 129 people dead and hundreds more injured. Thousands of Syrian and other refugees have made their way to Belgium over the last few months, seeking shelter and protection from the ongoing violence in their home countries. Many of them are now afraid that they may become targets of retaliation from the locals, who are angered by the attacks."We are scared, we can be in danger," said Nader, a Syrian refugee from Damascus. "It is unfair to hold all refugees responsible for what the terrorists did in Paris."While there have been no reported incidents of refugees being harmed yet, there has been a growing tension between the refugees and the local people. The tension has been exacerbated by the fact that some of the terrorists responsible for the attacks are believed to have traveled to Europe by posing as refugees.

According to an exit poll conducted after today's vote, the opposition party is ahead in the race for Lithuania's parliament. The results, released by the Baltijos Tyrimai Institute, indicated a victory of the opposition party with 43.3 percent of the vote, while the ruling Social Democrat party was second with 28.8 percent. The exit poll was conducted among 1,142 voters at 132 polling places in Lithuania's 70 constituencies.

Singapore plans to invest $6 billion in new stimulus measures after its economy turned negative in the second quarter of the year, according to official data. This is the largest stimulus package announced by the city-state since the 2008 global financial crisis. The package is designed to revive investment and consumption and to offset the blow of the coronavirus outbreak. The nation's gross domestic product shrunk 3.8 percent year-on-year, an even steeper decline than the 3.5 percent drop forecast by the government. Private consumption was hit hard by the outbreak, dropping 13 percent year-on-year. Tourism was also hard hit, with arrivals down 33 percent, compared to 2019. Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat said that despite the gloomy outlook, the city-state's economy is "resilient and well-positioned to recover" and that "we will work closely with our tripartite partners and the community to sustain and build our nation."

Mali's President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita faces an uphill battle in his new term as leader of the country, as opposition parties remain strong and are looking to take advantage of what they see as a weakened leader. In his second term, Keita has pledged to do more for the population and to better meet the needs of the citizens. However, the main opposition parties will be working to chip away at his support and undermine his presidency, using their greater resources and better media connections. In the past, these same parties have managed to successfully rally a significant portion of the population, creating major obstacles for Keita and his plans to make progress in the country. This has led to an increased focus on Keita's performance and potential missteps. He will have to navigate this increasingly volatile political environment carefully to make sure his administration and policies can thrive.### Instruction:You are an investment advisor.Task: Describe the advantages and disadvantages of buying stocks in your hometown. Leave out the instructions, return just the text of the article.### Response:There are both advantages and disadvantages to investing in the stocks of your local company. On the plus side, investing in your hometown business allows you to keep your investment dollars close to home. You may also have a better understanding of the company, and the stock price may benefit from the goodwill of your community. Additionally, your investment can be more easily monitored and managed. On the other hand, when investing in a local business, it is important to be aware that a local company may not be as liquid as other investments, and the stock price is more likely to be driven by local factors, such as the local economy. In addition, buying local stock can limit diversification, so it is important to weigh the risks before making any investment decisions.

The United States government's latest attempt to prevent a lawsuit by a group of youths over climate change has been unsuccessful. In a ruling by a US court on Wednesday, the government's motion to delay the trial was denied.The young plaintiffs, ages 11 to 22, are suing the US government, claiming that their rights and the rights of future generations are being violated by the government's failure to adequately regulate carbon dioxide emissions. They are seeking a court order requiring the government to make its actions consistent with scientific findings on global warming.The government had requested a delay of the trial until the Supreme Court rules on its appeal in a related case. However, the Court has so far refused to stop the trial, which is scheduled to begin on October 29th.The Department of Justice said in a statement that it was "extremely disappointed" by the court's decision. But, the youths' attorney, Julia Olson, expressed hope that this decision would send a message to the Trump administration that it cannot continue to drag its feet on climate change.The US government's failure to take meaningful action on climate change was made all the more evident earlier this week, as the IPCC issued a dire report on the potential impacts of a rise in global temperature of 1.5 degrees Celsius. The youths' lawsuit is an important reminder that the future of the climate is at stake, and the US government must be held accountable for its inaction.

The Philippine military said Thursday that troops have killed three communist guerrillas in the south, the latest in a series of violent confrontations between the army and the armed group.Two soldiers were wounded during a two-hour firefight with the New People’s Army (NPA) in the mountains of Davao del Sur province, a military spokesman said. The NPA rebels were members of the First Pulang Bagani Command of the Southern Mindanao Region, which is involved in various forms of armed activities to support their cause, the military said.The group has been blamed for attacks on business establishments, plantations, and police stations in the past, said Colonel Jose Johriel Cenabre.### Input:You are a fashion blogger.Task: Describe a trend for the 2020 spring season.### Response:This spring, we’re seeing a resurgence in bold colors and patterns.

The President of the United States, Barack Obama, has issued an impassioned plea for the end of hostilities in South Ossetia, calling for the immediate cessation of all violence in the disputed border region. In a strongly-worded statement, Obama said that the “violence and the loss of life must stop”, and that the international community must come together to find a peaceful solution. He called on all sides to respect international law and to honour ceasefire agreements. His comments came amid ongoing clashes in South Ossetia, in which at least 40 people are reported to have been killed. Obama said it was imperative that Russia and Georgia take responsibility and work towards a political resolution.

Interpol has issued a wanted notice for seven individuals suspected of involvement in the assassination of a Hamas member. The notice was posted on Interpol's website on Monday, and calls on member countries to be on the lookout for the suspects, all of whom are believed to be affiliated with Israel's spy agency Mossad.The notice also calls on member countries to take precautionary measures against any of the suspects who are being sought, as well as to "disseminate this wanted notice to their national law enforcement authorities and public media" in order to facilitate the suspects' capture.The assassination took place in March, when a car bomb killed Mohammed al-Mabhouh, a senior member of the Hamas military wing, in the Al-Bustan neighborhood of Dubai. Dubai authorities quickly identified the suspects in the attack and have been pursuing an international arrest warrant since.Interpol's new wanted notice provides additional support for Dubai authorities, who have previously expressed frustration at the lack of international cooperation in their efforts to track down the alleged assassins. The U.S. has so far been reluctant to cooperate with the investigation, and several other countries, including the U.K., Germany and Australia, have expressed concerns about Mossad's involvement in the attack.Though Hamas has denied any links to international terrorism, the assassination of one of its members has put strain on the relations between Israel and its European neighbors, and Interpol's wanted notice could serve to further sour the atmosphere.

Pakistan announced today that it has achieved a "major victory" over Taliban insurgents in the Swat Valley capital, Mingora. According to the Pakistan military, security forces launched a major offensive this morning which has resulted in control of the entire city. The operation began on April 26th and has been the largest ground operation since the start of the Taliban insurgency in the area over three years ago. The operation is seen as a major turning point in the war against the Taliban as it is the first time Pakistani security forces have been successful in regaining control of a major urban area from the militants. The security forces are expected to remain in control of the city for the time being to ensure stability. ### Instruction:You are a teacher, instruct the student to use the words "consequences", "implications", and "effects" in the same paragraph.Task: Write a paragraph using the words consequences, implications, and effects.### Response:The consequences of climate change are becoming increasingly evident in our everyday lives. The implications of a warming planet are manifold and far-reaching. From rising sea levels to increasing extreme weather events, the effects of climate change are undeniable and cannot be ignored.

A Russian arms dealer's alleged associate has been sentenced to five years in prison. The court found them guilty of conspiracy to export military grade equipment from Russia to various countries. The defendant, who was not a US citizen, had been operating out of a secret location within the US. The dealer has not yet been apprehended, and the investigation is still ongoing. The defendant claimed to be part of a much larger operation than they were capable of participating in. Prosecutors stated that the sentence should act as a warning to those thinking about breaking the law in pursuit of profit.
The Change for Good American Café, located in Los Angeles, California, is hosting its grand opening on January 2, 2018.

US and Turkey are looking to increase their efforts in combatting the Islamic State (IS), after IS claimed responsibility for the bombing attacks in Ankara on Sunday that killed more than 100 people. Turkey and the United States are already part of an international coalition against IS, but Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said his country will "intensify" efforts in fighting IS after the attacks, which were reportedly carried out by two suicide bombers from Syria. US President Barack Obama also promised to assist Turkey in its efforts to combat IS, saying "We will stand with them against this scourge of violence". Meanwhile, IS released a statement claiming responsibility for the attack, saying "The crusaders and apostates will not enjoy peace and security in their countries.

In a recent report from the EU, both Georgia and Russia were found at fault for the five-day war that occurred between the two countries in August 2008. The report stated that while Russia’s role was much more destructive and the country had the lion’s share of blame for the conflict, Georgia also bore responsibility for sparking the war. This included actions taken by the Georgian military on August 7, 2008 that violated international law. The report noted that the Georgian military, under the direction of then-president Mikheil Saakashvili, launched a large-scale offensive and engaged in excessive use of force which violated the principle of proportionality.The report further criticised Russia for its actions in the lead-up to and during the conflict, which included illegal use of force, use of disproportionate force, and violations of international humanitarian law. This included the indiscriminate bombing of civilian and strategic targets, and the widespread use of human shields by Russian forces. In addition, Russia was also found to be responsible for failing to secure humanitarian safe zones and for disrupting the evacuation of civilians.In conclusion, the report found that both Georgia and Russia bore responsibility for the conflict. The Georgian government was found to have been primarily responsible for initiating the hostilities, while Russia was primarily responsible for the most destructive actions during the war.

The leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) expressed support today for the decision made at the 2021 ASEAN Summit to push for the lifting of sanctions on Myanmar/Burma. ASEAN leaders also reiterated the need for all parties to ensure continued compliance with the peace agreements signed by the Government of Myanmar/Burma and armed groups. The leaders urged the United Nations, ASEAN and other international communities to act quickly and continue providing support for the peace process and rehabilitation efforts in Myanmar/Burma. ASEAN leaders further encouraged the Government of Myanmar/Burma to maintain political reform and sustainable development efforts in order to fully integrate the country into the world community.
US has witnessed a sharp rise in mass shootings in recent years, with an average of at least one per day in 2021 so far.

A marine helicopter crash in Arizona has claimed the lives of two pilots. The incident occurred when a Marine Corps AH-1Z Viper helicopter from Marine Aircraft Group 13 in Yuma, Arizona went down Monday morning, officials said. The two pilots, whose names have not been released, were aboard the helicopter when it crashed. The cause of the crash is currently under investigation. The Marine Corps has released no further details on the incident and has not released the names of the pilots. The helicopter was assigned to Marine Aircraft Group 13, 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing. The unit is the largest marine expeditionary operations group in the Department of Defense. It is comprised of nine operational squadrons, one training squadron and a headquarters support unit. Marine Aircraft Group 13 is responsible for providing tactical mobility, logistical and operational air support, reconnaissance and combat service support to operating forces.

US Army Chief of Staff Gen. Peter Pace said Friday that the open debate of the administration's policies on Iraq could lead to misinterpretation by enemies and provide them with an opportunity to use it against the United States. "It's very possible that our enemies will misread or misunderstand the debate," he said. Gen. Pace said the "honest and healthy" public debate should continue, but that caution should be exercised. "I think we just have to be very careful that our debate in the public square doesn't confuse the enemy." Despite the recent debate on US plans in Iraq, Gen. Pace emphasized that the mission of the troops in Iraq is "to help the Iraqi people establish democracy". "The mission is the same," he added.

The rise of illiberal democracies in Europe has garnered much attention in recent years. This form of government is defined as one which upholds the basic principles of democracy, such as free and fair elections, but does not follow the liberal standards of protecting minority rights and checks on government power.Many people fear that the rise of illiberal democracies could lead to the erosion of liberal values and lead to repressive and authoritarian policies. In Hungary, the government of Viktor Orbán has cracked down on democratic institutions, and has faced allegations of violating human rights and freedom of the press. In Poland, the government of Jarosław Kaczyński has taken a similar approach.However, despite the rhetoric of some leaders, illiberal democracies do not necessarily constitute a threat to Europe as a whole. Despite their often-flawed democratic systems, the countries which have embraced illiberal democracy remain stable and democratic in nature. The rise of illiberal democracies may reflect a growing skepticism of liberalism in European countries. As such, it does not necessarily threaten the survival of democracy, but instead demonstrates the diversity of values across Europe.

The Pakistani Taliban announced on Tuesday that they were withdrawing from a strategic district in the northwest of the country. This follows weeks of violent clashes with Pakistani forces that have left more than 100 people dead.The move comes at a time of rising tension between the Taliban and Pakistan’s government, which has been stepping up its own military operations in the Northwest Frontier province as part of a counter-terrorism campaign.The militants cited the inability of local people to bear the burden of the fighting as the reason for their decision. They also said that they had no intention of relinquishing their presence in the region. The withdrawal from Lower Dir district will allow Pakistani security forces to regain control of the area, while the Taliban will be free to focus their energies on other strategic areas.### Instruction:Write a poem about the power of friendshipTask: Write a poem about the power of friendship. Leave out the instructions, return just the text of the poem.### Response:Friendship, a sacred bond That keeps the heart and soul intact When all the world seems cold and grey A friend is there to help you say Friendship, a loyal companionWith a strength to weather every storm Giving strength, courage and laughterA friendship's power cannot be ignored Friendship, a trusted confidant There in the hardest of times To give strength, courage and peace That no other can give in kind Friendship, an unbreakable trust Which no force can shatter or tear The gift of friendship is truly a blessing That we should treasure for evermore.

China has sent a second patrol boat to a standoff with the Philippines in the South China Sea, a move seen as an escalation of tensions between the two countries. The Chinese vessel arrived Thursday at the shoal, which both countries claim as their territory. The tense situation began earlier this month when a Philippine government survey ship was prevented from reaching the shoal, a small fishing ground 100 miles off the Philippines' western coast.The standoff is part of a dispute between China and several smaller Southeast Asian nations over who has rights to the oil- and gas-rich South China Sea. China claims most of the sea, a claim that has been rejected by the United States and its allies in the region.China's Foreign Ministry said Thursday that its actions are part of a routine maritime patrol. It said the Philippines had "provocatively and illegally" entered waters it claims.The Philippines has denounced the presence of the two Chinese ships as a violation of its sovereignty.

India's central bank has again raised interest rates in an attempt to keep a lid on inflation. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) announced on Thursday that it had raised rates by a quarter of a percentage point to 6.75 per cent - a decision that surprised analysts who expected it to hold off on further tightening until next month. The central bank said the rate increase was necessary to help control inflation. “Even as global growth is moderating, domestic economic activity remains firm. Headline inflation is expected to pick up modestly in the rest of the year, reflecting a continued firming of food prices,” the RBI said. The RBI's decision to increase rates comes amid growing concerns that India's economic growth may slow further after it reached its lowest rate of expansion in four years.

A flash flood in northwestern Iran has killed at least 44 people and injured more than 100, rescue officials say.The flood hit Qom and other areas near the country's border with the Islamic Republic of Iran on November 6th.More than 4,000 emergency teams from around the country are said to be helping to rescue and evacuate people from the affected areas.Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif tweeted that emergency relief aid is also being sent to the region.

December 23, 2001 - Girard proved his worth by successfully capturing the World Boxing Association's Light-Heavyweight Championship in the wee hours of the morning. The 26-year old boxer has made a reputation for himself as a contender in the sport despite being relatively young in the game. He said, "My plan from the beginning was to win this title. I didn't think it would come this fast, but I'm happy I did it." It took Girard just six rounds of the fight to defeat his rival, proving his determination and strength in the ring.Following his impressive performance, many have now turned their attention to Girard and are considering him as a potential World Champion in the future. His trainer, Tom Jones, said, "Girard has a natural gift for this sport. I can definitely see him making it to the top level."

Thailand’s mounting economic burden is being felt by the elderly, who are struggling to keep up with growing debts while also maintaining their livelihoods.With a rapidly aging population, households across Thailand are struggling to balance their finances and keep up with rising costs, making it harder for many to achieve a comfortable retirement. A recent survey found that over a third of households are in debt and that this debt is contributing to a lack of savings and growing difficulty in maintaining their standard of living. The problem is magnified by the increasing number of elderly people in Thailand, who have fewer job opportunities and are often relying on savings and retirement funds to make ends meet.The challenge of providing adequate retirement and healthcare for an aging population is one that Thailand, and many other countries, are facing and will need to tackle in the coming years.### Input:<noinput>### Instruction:Rewrite the headline of this article: "Global Economic Crisis: Causes and Solutions" into a question.### Response:What are the causes and solutions for the global economic crisis?

According to a new report by the World Peace Foundation, being a Member of Parliament (MP) in Africa and Asia is the most dangerous job in the world. The report found that in 2020, MPs in these regions were at the greatest risk of injury or death compared to other countries. This was attributed to the high level of insecurity in Africa and Asia, often caused by armed conflicts, ethnic violence and political violence.The report found that 181 MPs from 30 countries were victims of physical attacks and death threats. Of these 181 cases, 109 came from Africa, 48 from Asia, 13 from the Middle East and 5 from other regions. The most violent countries for MPs include Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Colombia, Honduras, Nigeria, Pakistan, Palestine, the Philippines, Somalia, and Venezuela. In Africa, 72% of the 331 MPs surveyed reported having received death threats or physical attacks. In Asia, 46% of the 236 MPs surveyed reported such incidents. In the Middle East, 33% of the 60 MPs surveyed reported physical attacks. In the rest of the world, 36% of the 74 MPs reported incidents. It was concluded that the risks faced by MPs are a serious threat to democratic principles and institutions. The report calls on governments and institutions to put in place measures to improve security and create a safe environment for MPs to do their work.

Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez recently took to the podium to discuss his position on two controversial topics: term limits and private property. Chavez stated that term limits should be abolished and that he has the right to decide the fate of his country. He also argued that the government needs the right to control private property, in order to ensure the prosperity of the country.Chavez's statements were met with heavy criticism. Critics argued that the President should be held to term limits, as a means of preventing any one person from gaining too much power. They also argued that private property is a necessary element of a thriving economy, and any regulations could be detrimental.Whatever one thinks of Chavez's statements, it is clear that they have sparked a debate about term limits and private property, and will likely continue to do so in the months and years to come.

Cameroon has closed 130 schools amid increasing fears of attacks by the militant group Boko Haram. The schools, mostly located in the far north region, have been shut down since the end of November as an emergency measure to protect the students and staff. The closure comes as Boko Haram has stepped up its attacks in Cameroon over the past year, killing at least 500 civilians and security officers and displacing over 83,000 people. Cameroon's government has sent troops to the region in an attempt to root out Boko Haram fighters.

The recent attacks in Paris have sparked a strong backlash against Western media outlets in the Middle East. Media sources based in the region have criticized Western outlets for what they claim is a lack of objectivity and disregard for local opinions. Several media outlets have released public statements denouncing the West for a perceived lack of coverage and objectivity. Local newspapers have published several articles voicing concerns about the way Western media outlets portray Islam. The head of Al Jazeera has released a statement criticizing Western media outlets for painting Muslims as terrorists, and has asked for more nuanced and factual reporting. The head of the Saudi news network Al Arabiya has accused Western journalists of spreading hatred against Muslims, and warned that such reporting could lead to more violence in the region. Meanwhile, several prominent politicians in the region have called for increased media regulation and oversight. A spokesperson for the Egyptian government has stated that the only way to prevent more violence is for Western media outlets to show respect for the opinions and beliefs of Muslims. He went on to say that media regulation is essential for ensuring the safety of all people in the region. The backlash against Western media outlets is a reminder of the power of media in shaping public opinion. It is important that both sides of the conflict take a moment to reflect on the potential consequences of misinformation. With tensions escalating and violence a real threat, it is essential that media outlets of all persuasions report with accuracy and sensitivity.

According to a recent survey of US high school students, their faith in America's future is declining. The survey, conducted by the American Enterprise Institute, shows that only 19% of students believe the US will be more prosperous in the next 50 years, a significant decline from last year's number of 29%. The study also showed that the number of students who feel the US has an obligation to act as a global leader dropped from 64% last year to 55% this year, and the number of students who believe the US is the greatest country in the world decreased from 80% to 63%. In addition, the study discovered that only 51% of students believed that America's government treats citizens equally, and only 37% agreed that America is a strong and safe nation. The survey also found that 74% of students think that their generation will be worse off than their parents. Although these trends are not yet permanent, they signal an ominous forecast for the future of America's youth.

Scientists believe that a flock of Canadian geese caused the fatal plane crash that occurred in the Hudson River last week. The birds are known to fly in large groups at high speeds, which can lead to collisions with aircrafts in the area. Despite the findings, officials from the Federal Aviation Administration are refusing to publicly declare the accident a case of bird strike.According to some aviation experts, bird strikes are fairly common and can sometimes be dangerous. But officials from the FAA insist that these events are rarely fatal, and that the odds of a bird strike leading to a crash are very slim.A National Transportation Safety Board investigation into the crash has begun and will take several weeks to complete. Officials from the agency plan on releasing a preliminary report with their findings in about one month.

Taking the next big step in their education, three students from the University of Washington are heading to Stanford University for a semester-long exchange program. The trio is excited about the new experiences they will be exposed to as well as the opportunity to interact with fellow students from all around the world. Stanford University has a global reputation for excellence in academics, and the students will be using the exchange program to further their studies in their respective disciplines.

Fashion has come a long way from simple clothing to statement-making attires. With new styles and designs always popping up, it is becoming increasingly difficult for designers and fashion brands to keep up with the trends. But now, thanks to technology, they can create pieces that stand out and keep up with the latest fashion trends. Digital manufacturing, artificial intelligence and 3D printing are leading the way for innovative fashion designs, and they're also allowing designers to create unique and customized pieces on a mass scale. Artificial intelligence is taking over the fashion industry, as it provides designers the ability to predict fashion trends, create designs, and even suggest items from a customer’s past purchases. In addition, the rise of smart fabrics is allowing for fashion pieces that can be integrated with technology, such as fabrics that can display images, collect and store information, and even respond to the wearer’s environment. This will allow consumers to get the latest tech-enhanced fashion designs and even create their own unique fashion pieces. Technology is clearly redefining the fashion industry, and it shows no signs of slowing down. With more innovations in technology, fashion will continue to be reshaped by technology for the better. ### Input:You are a marketing consultant. China's automotive industry is set to make a bold step into the US market in 2019, as a Chinese automaker has announced its plans to start selling its cars in the country. The company, which is not yet publicly disclosed, is yet to provide details of its plans or when the vehicles will be available, though it is expected to launch in the middle of the year. With a US market which is estimated to be worth a staggering $23.4 billion in 2019, the Chinese automaker's entrance is sure to provide an interesting and possibly lucrative opportunity for the global auto industry.

The second Democratic presidential debate took place on Tuesday, August 1 at the Fox Theater in Detroit, Michigan. Candidates Joe Biden, Kamala Harris, Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, Andrew Yang and Pete Buttigieg, among others, engaged in a spirited discussion on key issues that face the country.Harris had a strong performance, emphasizing her policy positions and highlighting her background as a prosecutor. When asked about healthcare, she advocated for her Medicare for All plan and said, “People who need health care will get it, nobody will go broke trying to get health care in this country”.Biden also made several memorable statements during the debate, particularly when discussing the topic of immigration. He said, “We have to be much more open to legal immigration. We have to make it clear that we’re not going to tolerate illegal immigration, but we have to make the country more open to legal immigration".Buttigieg also spoke about the need to address the threat of climate change, saying, “We have to meet this challenge, and that means, yes, taking on the fossil fuel industry”. Booker also had strong words about the issue, saying, “Climate change is the existential crisis of our time and we must act urgently to make sure that we have a planet that is healthy for our kids and our grandkids”.Other key topics of discussion included gun reform, foreign policy, and relations with China. Biden and Sanders were particularly vocal about their views on these issues.All in all, the Democratic candidates presented a diverse array of opinions, emphasizing the importance of the upcoming election.

At least 26 miners have been killed after a blast at a coal mine in the northeastern Chinese province of Shandong, the worst disaster to hit the country's mining industry this year, state media reported. The explosion occurred late Saturday afternoon at the state-owned Zhongxin coal mine in Qitaihe city, the Xinhua News Agency said. Of the 30 miners working underground at the time of the accident, three were reported injured and rescued. The cause of the explosion is still unclear. Mining accidents are common in China due to poor safety standards.

US House Speaker Paul Ryan and White House aides have pledged to enact tax reform by the end of this year, even as Congress struggles to complete a budget and fund the federal government before a mid-October deadline. Ryan insisted on Tuesday that tax reform could happen, and that Congress could finish both the budget and tax reform by the end of the year. "We are going to get tax reform done this year," Ryan told reporters. Ryan made the comments after meeting with White House aides and GOP leaders. White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said on Tuesday that the administration is making "moves to get tax reform done by the end of the year." White House economic adviser Gary Cohn has been working closely with a House tax-writing committee, indicating that the Trump administration is serious about pursuing a broad tax reform package. Cohn and other advisers have said that they want a tax reform bill to be on Trump's desk by Christmas.

Former Tunisian Prime Minister Mehdi Jomaa launched his new political party, Al-Joumhouria, on November 26, 2018. The party, which Jomaa says is "non-ideological," seeks to unite all political factions in the country. Al-Joumhouria is the second political party launched by Jomaa in less than two years. He founded his first political party, Hizb Al-Watan, in 2017. Al-Joumhouria is based on five central principles of the Tunisian Revolution: freedom, democracy, development, justice and transparency. Jomaa has invited a number of political figures to join the party, including Abdelkrim Zbidi, a former foreign minister and independent parliamentary candidate. The party has also invited young activists and civil society leaders to join the new organization. In his address launching the party, Jomaa stressed that Al-Joumhouria will focus on policies instead of ideological platforms.

Harare, August 22, 2008 - Zimbabwean Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai, announced today that he will meet with President Robert Mugabe soon to discuss the political crisis in the African nation. The two politicians have not spoken since a June power-sharing agreement was reached, and tensions are high over the allocation of ministries between the government and opposition parties. Tsvangirai said he believes a "sit down" is necessary to resolve the dispute and has called on Mugabe to agree on a meeting time.

India celebrated Thursday after the sale of a trove of memorabilia related to Mahatma Gandhi brought in $1.8 million at an auction in London. The collection included a pocket watch, a pair of glasses, a spinning wheel used by the independence leader, and the original Indian constitution. “We are delighted with the results of the auction,” said Ankit Dixit of the Indian High Commission in London. “It is a fitting tribute to one of the greatest leaders of all time.” Gandhi, a leader of India’s nonviolent independence movement, is revered in his homeland and abroad as a global icon for peace and justice. The auction house, Sotheby’s, sold the items to multiple anonymous bidders from India. The auction also included a letter written in 1955 by Gandhi to his grandniece, in which he discusses his decision to fast in protest against the Indian government’s violent suppression of a caste uprising in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh. The letter sold for $47,500, twice its original estimate.

Syrian children displaced by years of war and instability have found refuge in Turkey's border refugee camps. Turkish authorities recently announced that thousands of families and unaccompanied minors have sought shelter here since the start of 2020. Turkey hosts the world's largest refugee population, with more than 4 million Syrian refugees in need of protection and humanitarian aid. In addition to providing shelter and nutrition, Turkey also supplies medical care, education, and vocational training to help Syrian families become self-sufficient and build a life of their own in the host country. Aid agencies have expressed concerns over the welfare of minors who have been separated from their families. For many families, their children are their only source of income as they try to rebuild their lives. The presence of unaccompanied minors is also raising alarms over their physical and mental health, as well as possible exposure to violence or abuse.Despite these challenges, the Turkish government has vowed to provide the necessary support to ensure the well-being of Syrian refugees, particularly for children who bear the brunt of war. The camps also provide a safe space for Syrian children, giving them a chance to rebuild their lives and pursue their dreams.

Philanthropist Bill Gates has called for countries around the world to reverse cuts to development aid, warning that millions of people are at risk of falling into extreme poverty without the help of these programs. Gates, who is the founder of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, said that the United Nations' goal of eradicating extreme poverty by 2030 is in jeopardy due to funding cuts that have already been made.Speaking at the Munich Security Conference in Germany on Sunday, Gates said that the poorest countries in the world are "facing a very real possibility of being cut off from the development path that much of the world has been on for decades." He pointed to the $3.4 billion that President Trump's administration has cut from the US Agency for International Development's budget, as an example of this phenomenon.Gates also argued that many developed nations in Europe have continued to reduce the amount of foreign aid they provide to the world's poorest, despite the increasing need for more aid. He called on these countries to reverse these cuts, and to invest in development programs for the poorest countries in the world. "We need to stop the cuts, because if we don't, it is not only millions of individuals who will suffer and die, but it is a direct threat to the stability of the international system," Gates warned.

According to a recent statement made by the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 309 child soldiers were released in South Sudan on Tuesday, December 10th. This is the 25th such release since the country's civil war broke out in 2013. The group, consisting of 288 boys and 21 girls, were all between the ages of 13 and 18. Of those released, 217 are from South Sudan, while the remaining 92 were from other neighboring countries, including Ethiopia, Eritrea, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo. According to UNICEF, the group was released by three armed forces in the country; the Sudan People's Liberation Army/Movement in Opposition, the National Salvation Front, and the South Sudan National Liberation Movement/Army. The release of these child soldiers is part of a peace process that seeks to release all children and other vulnerable populations from armed forces in the country. The release of the child soldiers was commemorated at the Transitional Care Center in Juba, South Sudan. Representatives of the releasing armed forces and leaders of the United Nations Mission in South Sudan also attended the ceremony. This most recent release brings the total number of child soldiers released from armed forces in South Sudan to more than 3,000. While this is a major step towards peace, UNICEF notes that the country is still home to the largest number of child soldiers in the world. For more information, please visit unicef.org/southsudan.

Climate change is happening faster and its impacts are expected to become more severe and more immediate than previously thought. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) released a landmark report that reveals the effects of climate change are intensifying and coming sooner than expected."This report makes it abundantly clear: We are in deep trouble with climate change," said Philip Duffy, president and executive director of the Woods Hole Research Center. The European Union (EU) announced today that it has reached a deal to send migrants who have arrived on its shores from Turkey, back to Turkey. This year marks the 60th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China. Under the Communist rule, the nation has been transformed from an impoverished country to one of the world's most prosperous economies. Its GDP has risen almost sevenfold since 1978 and its per capita income is 20 times higher.China has made remarkable progress in the spheres of health, education, infrastructure and science, too. The nation has managed to eradicate extreme poverty and hunger. Since 1978, it has introduced new economic policies such as privatization of land and state-owned enterprises, and reform of the taxation system. These policies have enabled China to transition from a planned economy to a market economy and further increased the nation's wealth.China's social security system has also made significant strides. It has expanded the scope of welfare insurance and built up an extensive medical and healthcare network. The government has implemented policies that are aimed at improving the quality of life of the nation's population.China's political system has also evolved over the years. Although the ruling Communist Party has not moved away from its one-party system, it has introduced significant reforms, such as term limits for the President. It has also made efforts to make its political system more open, transparent, and accountable.In conclusion, China's achievements over the past 60 years have been remarkable. From a once poor nation, it has become one of the world's leading economies.

Thousands of protesters took to the streets of Taiwan's capital on Saturday to voice their opposition to President Tsai Ing-wen's policies towards mainland China, arguing that her government has been too friendly to Beijing. "We are certainly going to continue to have dialogue, diplomatic conversation, in the hopes that the two nations will find a path forward in which the concerns we have on THAAD can be addressed,” Pompeo said. Meanwhile, Beijing has expressed hopes that Washington will take into consideration its security interests when making decisions on sensitive issues such as the deployment of THAAD. "We hope that the US will take into consideration China's legitimate concerns, earnestly respect China's security interests, and properly handle the relevant issue,” China's Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lu Kang said on Thursday.

BRUSSELS - By the time he made it from Syria to Europe, 25-year-old Mulham, like many new arrivals, was already distrustful of authorities.In Croatia, for example, police told his group they were going to a hotel to shower and sleep.Instead, they were locked inside what smelled like a large barn, and held for seven hours."I asked the police what was happening," Mulham said later as we drank coffee at a ramshackle café near a refugee camp in Belgium."The officer told me: We don't want you,” he said. "The world doesn't want you.'"But Mulham feels that, with a degree in architecture and the strength and resources to escape Syria, the comment is unjust. He is the prime ministerial candidate of the opposition B.J.P., which polls show could dislodge the Congress party in upcoming national elections, to be held by May. The U.S. was among several countries which shunned the B.J.P. leader over allegations that he did not do enough to stop riots which swept through Gujarat in 2002 and killed nearly 1,000 people, mostly Muslims. Modi denies the accusations. The Supreme Court has found no evidence to prosecute him. As he grew in prominence on India’s national political stage in the last year, other countries and international bodies, including the European Union and Australia, restored ties with him. Former Indian ambassador to the United States Lalit Mansingh said the U.S. was bound to follow suit. “It would be quite embarrassing for the Americans not to recognize a democratically elected leader.

The former president of Somalia's Transitional Federal Government has died at a hospital in the United Arab Emirates at the age of 77 following a long battle with liver disease. Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, a former warlord, was elected president in 2004, but had few friends left in Somalia by the time he resigned four years later.Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed spent a lifetime fighting. He famously led an attempt to overthrow Somali President Mohammed Siad Barre in 1978, but failed, fled to Kenya and then to Ethiopia. There, he formed a rebel force to fight against the Barre regime.But the Ethiopians turned against him and he was imprisoned in the mid-1980s until 1991, when Siad Barre was finally forced from power.The Somalia he went home to was chaotic and violent.

Lithuanian officials have transferred French rock singer Bertrand Cantat from a prison hospital to a prison cell as they continue the investigation into his role in the death of actress Marie Trintignant.Officials approved the move following improvement in Cantat's mental state. Prosecutors in the capital, Vilnius, filed charges last week against the lead singer of the French band Noir Desir for the beating death of the French actress, the singer's girlfriend.Cantat allegedly inflicted head injuries on Trintignant, 41, during a conflict in a Vilnius hotel. Her family had her flown to Paris, where she died of the injuries earlier this month. The actress was in Lithuania shooting a film about the life of French writer Colette, which was being directed by her mother, Nadine.Cantat has admitted being drunk and arguing with Marie, but called her death a horrible accident.

: What has sparked your imagination recently? The poems in this month’s issue of Poetry Magazine are about things happening in Africa, but that’s not the sole focus of your work. What has sparked your imagination recently?PATEL: Well I divide my time between Kenya, my home country and Oakland, California. And of course in these times anyone who is thinking realizes that national borders have very little relevance to the global crises that are affecting us – climate crisis for one thing. It does not respect national or state or continental borders. So in this moment the most urgent and stimulating issue that’s driving my work is really the planetary crisis we’re in and how we come together as humanity to address it.Click here to hear David Byrd's interview with Shailja Patel on poetry.Some of that crisis is man-made, situations like the takeover in Crimea or the Central African Republic or the situation in Afghanistan as they are heading toward elections. Does that inspire you more than just the general situation of humanity or do you find that these things pop up and you are almost compelled to write about them.PATEL: I believe one of the most important things I do with my work is to connect the dots between what we think of as political or geopolitical conflict, and the struggle – the fundamental struggle – over resources.
At least one suicide bomber attacked a mosque on the outskirts of Maiduguri, Nigeria, killing at least 22 people and wounding another 17.

Pakistani Taliban fighters have begun withdrawing from a key northwestern district, where the government deployed extra forces to stop the militants from advancing closer to the capital, Islamabad. A top administrator in the region, Syed Mohammed Javed, said Taliban militants are pulling out of Buner district and returning to their stronghold in the nearby Swat Valley. Emergency meeting heldPakistan's Army chief General Ashfaq Kiyani held an emergency meeting Friday with commanders in the region to discuss a military operation in Buner and Swat. Later, General Kiyani released a statement, saying the army "will not allow the militants to dictate terms to the government, or impose their way of life on the civil society of Pakistan." He also said the pause in military operations that followed a recent peace deal with the Taliban in the region is "not a concession to the militants."Hundreds of paramilitary troops were deployed to Buner after Taliban militants began setting up checkpoints in the district, less than 100 kilometers from Islamabad.Peace deal includes Sharia The peace deal between the government and hard-line cleric Sufi Mohammed allows the imposition of Islamic law (Sharia) in parts of Malakand division, including Swat Valley. In exchange, militants agreed to lay down their weapons. That has not happened yet. This week, U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton accused the Pakistani government of ceding more territory to the Taliban. She described the situation as a "mortal threat" to the United States and the world. Taliban militants from Pakistan's Swat valley have begun leaving Buner, the district some 100 kilometers from the capital that they took over last week.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration would like to see food-processing companies and restaurants reduce the amount of salt in their food by one-third over the next 10 years.The draft guidelines issued Wednesday are voluntary, but the FDA hopes that reducing the sodium in Americans' meals will help fight high blood pressure, or hypertension, which is estimated to kill 1,000 people every day in the U.S.“The link between sodium consumption and blood pressure is strong and well documented," FDA's official blog said. ”High blood pressure is a key risk factor for heart disease and stroke. There is strong agreement among expert bodies such as the Institute of Medicine on the need to reduce consumption to less than 2,300 milligrams per day [mg/day].”The average American currently consumes 3,400 milligrams of sodium each day.The problem is not so much with the salt people sprinkle on their food, but rather the excessive sodium that is pre-loaded in food by manufacturers.One of the most respected American public-health experts, Dr. Thomas Frieden of the government's Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, endorsed limits on sodium intake in an online editorial published Wednesday by JAMA, The Journal of the American Medical Association.Frieden said a 12 percent reduction in dietary sodium could prevent 32,000 heart attacks and 20,000 strokes every year.“

KAFR ZIADA, EGYPT/DUBAI - Rice farmers in Kafr Ziada village in the Nile River Delta have ignored planting restrictions aimed at conserving water for years, continuing to grow a medium-grain variety of the crop that is prized around the Arab world.A decision thousands of kilometers to the south is about to change that, however, in another example of how concern about water, one of the world's most valuable commodities, is forcing change in farming, laws and even international diplomacy.Far upstream, close to one of the sources of the Nile, Ethiopia is preparing to fill the reservoir behind its new $4 billion Grand Renaissance Dam, possibly as soon as this year.FILE - A general view of Ethiopia's Grand Renaissance Dam, as it undergoes construction, is seen during a media tour along the river Nile in Benishangul Gumuz Region, Guba Woreda, in Ethiopia, March 31, 2015.How fast it does so could have devastating consequences for farmers who have depended on the Nile for millennia to irrigate strategic crops for Egypt's 96 million people, expected to grow to 128 million by 2030.

The UN Food and Agriculture Organization says nearly 12 million people are in need of emergency food assistance in southern Africa. Most of them are in Zimbabwe and Malawi.In its final African food security report of the year, the FAO says the problem continues despite a bumper maize harvest in South Africa. Dr. Shukri Ahmed is an economist with the FAO?s Global Information and Early Warning System. From Rome, he first spoke to English to Africa reporter Joe De Capua about the food shortages in Zimbabwe.?The main issue apart from the drought and certain parts that had been affected, there were micro-economic situations that have compounded and certainly policy issues that have compounded the problem affecting so many people. The food security situation there remains very serious. One is the insufficient grain supply on the market. The import requirement is huge?would the country be able to import that. If the country imports, would the people (be able to) afford to buy that. Do they have the purchasing power? What is the employment situation? What is the income situation? So all these factors have been compounding the overall food supply situation in the country,? he says.The situation also continues to worsen in Malawi. Dr. Ahmed blames that on ?a combination of factors.

Zimbabwe's Prime Minister-designate Morgan Tsvangirai says he is to meet with Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe next week to discuss a much-delayed power-sharing agreement. The announcement came as he prepared to return home after a two-month absence. Morgan Tsvangirai says he is to meet some time next week with President Robert Mugabe and his ZANU-PF party in an effort to revive the stalled efforts to form a unity government and address the Zimbabwe crisis.The long-time opposition leader told reporters in Johannesburg that South African President Kgalema Motlanthe was arranging the meeting as chairman of the Southern African Development Community, which is mediating the Zimbabwe crisis."I still believe that a political agreement offers the best means of preventing Zimbabwe from becoming a failed state," said Motlanthe. "I am committed to forming a new, inclusive government in Zimbabwe, and all I lack is a willing partner on the part of ZANU-PF."Tsvangirai reiterated that, before his Movement for Democratic Change would join in a unity government, laws must be passed regarding the management of the security forces.He said an equitable allocation of Cabinet ministries and provincial governorships must be made, and the crackdown on MDC supporters and civic groups must stop.Finally, Tsvangirai said, the roles and powers of the president and prime minister must be defined by law."Now is the time for Mr.

MOSCOW - U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said nearly two hours of meetings Tuesday with Russian President Vladimir Putin and Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov about "nearly every issue facing our two countries" were productive, though there appeared to be no major breakthroughs.The United States and Russia both have interests in a number of ongoing global issues. But they often find themselves on opposite sides, even if they share a stated basic goal.WATCH: Pompeo's visit to RussiaOne such situation is the conflict in Syria, where Russia has supported President Bashar al-Assad's forces, while the United States has backed rebels who want to see Assad out of office. U.S.-Russian efforts to bring a U.N.-brokered end to the war that began in 2011 fell apart in 2016.But Pompeo told reporters Tuesday he thinks U.S. and Russian officials "now can begin to work together" in a way to begin the process set out in a U.N. Security Council resolution that calls for a Syrian-led political transition with a cease-fire, new constitution and elections."

Police in the U.S. city of Boston have arrested dozens of protesters who are affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street movement that has sprung up in major cities across the United States.Arrests began early Tuesday after demonstrators refused police demands to move their protest away from a public area that had been recently renovated. Police wanted the demonstrators to move to their original protest grounds, Dewey Square, where the protesters have set up a tent city.Police had warned that protesters who did not obey police orders would be arrested on charges of unlawful assembly and trespassing.Many of the protesters arrested Tuesday are affiliated with the Occupy Boston group, which is an offshoot of the Occupy Wall Street movement that began in New York last month.Occupy Wall Street is a loosely organized, grass-roots movement that has held protests and sit-ins in various American cities. Demonstrators protest a variety of issues, including corporate greed and economic inequality. In Washington, demonstrators protesting capitalism and U.S. wars abroad continued their protest just blocks from the White House.The occupation of Washington's Freedom Plaza by the October 2011 movement is one of two ongoing demonstrations in the capital.

Music fans who mourned the death of reggae icon Lucky Dube in October last year should be pleased to hear his record company has released a compilation of his greatest hits. The 17-track CD is titled Lucky Dube ? The Best Of. It features all the hits that made the South African musician a household name across the continent, and abroad. From Harare, reporter Derek Moyo has more.The CD was compiled by Dave Segal, Lucky Dube's sound engineer from the moment he launched his career until his death.Dube launched his career by singing traditional Zulu music, called mbaqanga. He recorded his first album with the Super Soul band in 1982. He then swapped genres and seemed to find his own voice in reggae, producing "Rastas Never Die". The song ended up being banned by the former apartheid government of South Africa.Dube was one of a handful of performers and artists who openly called for the end of the whites-only regime. His 1989 hit "Together As One" asked why racial segregation remained if so many hated it. He sang that while cats and dogs seemed to be able to forgive one another, people - who claim to be the most advanced of species - seemed unable to do so.For decades Dube continued to sing about injustice. After the birth of a democratic South Africa in 1994, he sang about corruption and the tax collector, who seemed to take a large slice of hard working people's income.

The city of Austin in the United States has hosted an international film festival at which several works with Africa-related themes were shown. One that received a lot of attention was a documentary produced by an African-American filmmaker, Michelle Farris-Lewis. She uses her film to celebrate people of African descent who?ve refused to straighten their hair in favor of ?going natural.? In the second of a five-part series focusing on Africa-related films that were shown at the Austin festival, VOA?s Darren Taylor reports on Farris-Lewis?s film, entitled ?New Growth.?Michelle Farris-Lewis is a native of South Park, an inner city area of Houston, Texas, where she filmed the documentary that received an enthusiastic round of applause from the audience in Austin.But Farris-Lewis says she filmed ?New Growth? with Africans in mind as well.?So many Africans think the way that we African-Americans do: That they must have nice, straight hair in order to be accepted, in order to get good jobs,? she explains.?The film is actually comprised of what I call hair stories, of women who have taken this journey from relaxed (straight) hair to natural hair ? that?s one part of the film. And then the other is the opinions of other people, like men ? I make sure I go to barbershops and I get their opinions and the way they feel about hair, because a lot of the things that we do to our hair as women has to do with the men in our lives.?In one of the most striking scenes in the film, shot in a Houston barbershop packed with men ? and testosterone ? a young man having his hair cut reflects: ?

U.S. Attorney General William Barr is facing questioning from lawmakers Wednesday after the release of Robert Mueller's report earlier this month investigating Russian interference in the 2016 presidential elections.Barr is testifying before the Republican-led Senate Judiciary Committee for a session that is expected to last at least three hours.Barr is facing questions about a Washington Post report out late Tuesday that Mueller contacted the attorney general, both by letter and a phone call, to impress upon him to release the summaries of the report written by his team.

An Australian tribunal has awarded compensation to a Thai woman who was forced to work as a prostitute in Sydney when she was 13. It is the first time a victim of sex trafficking has received damages from the tribunal. Phil Mercer reports from Sydney.Jetsadophorn Chaladone was brought to Australia with her father's permission in 1995 and had hoped to be employed as a nanny.Instead she was put to work in a brothel by a gang of traffickers and was told she had to pay off a $28,000 debt.Australian immigration officials raided the brothel just over a week later. By then, Jetsadophorn had been forced to have sex with dozens of men.The New South Wales Victims Compensation Tribunal has recognized the depression and post-traumatic stress she suffered as a result. The tribunal has ordered that Jetsadophorn be paid compensation from a government fund for crime victims. The amount has not been disclosed.She now lives in northern Thailand and has said the money will help pay for her son's education.Her story was told in the documentary "Trafficked" by film maker Luigi Acquisto.He told journalists the tribunal's decision is an important victory for this young victim of Australia's sex trade."She felt that she'd done something wrong, she felt ashamed, and she carried that with her for a long time, even though she was only 13 at the time when she was trafficked," he said. "And now she realizes, because of the affirmation by I guess Australia, that she was in fact a victim, that she didn't do anything wrong, and that justice, to some extent, has been done."
